explanatory comments/crosstagging: The third ‘moment’ important for our purposes is the Nehruvian period after independence has been won in 1947. (I have used an inclusive post-1947 period for examples, going beyond Nehru’s death. However, images and artifacts produced from the 1990s doubtless should be considered a fourth such ‘moment’. Since the continuities of what I am treating as the Nehruvian period have been disrupted in that fourth moment, it deserves a separate treatment; see, for instance, Rajagopal’s image-essay. It is not considered here, given that much examination of that moment is included in other image-essays posted in Tasveer Ghar.) Popular visual culture in the third ‘moment’ of the Nehruvian era moves out from the Indian perspective that emerged in the preceding ‘moment,’ to encompass an even broader vision of Indian life as millions should live it. An emphasis on new technologies improving everyday life expands to show not only better life for all, but rediscovered occupations and forms of labor. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: As the mother uses new technologies to groom her children, she is also preparing them to be residents of a new world. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)
